docs.title: proj-type
docs.text:
Detect and display the current project type.

Usage: 

proj-type [directory]

Output: - Project name - Project type (R Package, Quarto, Research, etc.) - Storage location (local, google-drive, etc.) - Storage tier (active, stable, archive, etc.) - Claude instruction status - Git status

Examples: 

# Check current directory
proj-type

# Check specific directory
proj-type ~/R-packages/active/rmediation

docs.title: proj-info
docs.text:
Display comprehensive project information with context.

Usage: 

proj-info [directory]

Output: - Full project context - Claude instruction files - Git status and branch info - Type-specific information (R package stats, etc.) - Project structure tree

Examples: 

# Show info for current project
proj-info

# Show info for specific project
proj-info ~/quarto-projects/extensions/unm-revealjs

docs.title: claude-ctx
docs.text:
Gather and display all Claude context files in the current project.

Usage: 

claude-ctx [directory]

Output: - List of CLAUDE.md files - Claude settings files - Content of primary CLAUDE.md

Examples: 

# Show Claude context for current project
claude-ctx

# Show for specific project
claude-ctx ~/R-packages/active/medfit

docs.title: claude-init
docs.text:
Create a new CLAUDE.md file from template based on project type.

Usage: 

claude-init [directory]

Behavior: - Auto-detects project type - Selects appropriate template - Fills in project name and description - Creates CLAUDE.md in project root

Supported project types: - R Package → Uses CLAUDE-rpkg.md template - Quarto Project → Uses CLAUDE-quarto.md template - Research Project → Uses CLAUDE-research.md template

Examples: 

# Create CLAUDE.md in current directory
claude-init

# Create for specific project
claude-init ~/R-packages/active/probmed

docs.title: claude-show
docs.text:
Display the content of CLAUDE.md for the current project.

Usage: 

claude-show [directory]

Behavior: - Finds primary CLAUDE.md file - Uses bat for syntax highlighting (if available) - Falls back to cat if bat not installed

Priority: 1. CLAUDE.md in project root 2. .claude/CLAUDE.md 3. First CLAUDE*.md file found

Examples: 

# Show CLAUDE.md
claude-show

# Show for specific project
claude-show ~/R-packages/active/rmediation

docs.title: proj-claude
docs.text:
Open Claude Code with automatic project context.

Usage: 

proj-claude [directory]

Behavior: - Checks for CLAUDE.md (warns if missing) - Shows context summary - Opens Claude Code in chat mode

Examples: 

# Open Claude Code for current project
proj-claude

# Open for specific project
cd ~/R-packages/active/mediationverse
proj-claude

docs.title: workflow-run
docs.text:
Universal workflow dispatcher for running automated workflows.

Usage: 

workflow-run [workflow-name] [options]

Workflow Names: - dev - Run development workflow for current project type - test - Run testing workflow - deploy - Run deployment workflow - list - List available workflows for current project - info <name> - Show workflow details

Options: - -h, --help - Show help message - -c, --continue - Continue on errors (don't stop at first failure) - -i, --info - Show workflow info without running - --dry-run - Show what would be executed without running

Examples: 

# Run development workflow
workflow-run dev

# Run tests
workflow-run test

# List available workflows
workflow-run list

# Show workflow details
workflow-run info dev

# Run with continue-on-error
workflow-run dev --continue

# Dry run (preview)
workflow-run test --dry-run

Available Workflows: - R Packages: dev, test, pre-commit, build, check - Quarto Projects: preview, render, publish - Custom: Create .workflows/ directory in project

docs.title: rpkg-setup
docs.text:
Smart R package initialization with integrated workflows and claude-r-dev support.

Usage: 

rpkg-setup <package-name> [options]

Options: - -t, --type TYPE - Package type: standard, statistical, data-analysis, shiny (default: standard) - --tier TIER - Storage tier: active, stable, scratch (default: active) - --claude-r-dev - Install claude-r-dev configuration - --no-claude-r-dev - Skip claude-r-dev installation (default: auto-detect) - --profiles PROFILES - Comma-separated claude-r-dev profiles (default: auto-selected) - --skills - Activate recommended Claude skills - --no-skills - Don't activate skills (default: activate if available) - -h, --help - Show help message

Examples: 

# Create standard R package
rpkg-setup mypackage

# Create statistical methods package
rpkg-setup causalmed --type statistical

# Create in stable tier
rpkg-setup dataviz --type data-analysis --tier stable

# Create with custom profiles
rpkg-setup analysis --profiles base,data-analysis

# Create without claude-r-dev
rpkg-setup simple --no-claude-r-dev

Package Types: - standard - Standard R package (default) - statistical - Statistical methods and causal inference - data-analysis - Data analysis and visualization - shiny - Shiny web applications

What It Does: 1. Creates R package structure in appropriate tier directory 2. Installs claude-r-dev configuration (if available) 3. Activates recommended Claude skills 4. Creates CLAUDE.md from template 5. Initializes git repository 6. Sets up development workflows

docs.title: skill-activate
docs.text:
Manage Claude skills for the current project.

Usage: 

skill-activate [command] [options]

Commands: - <skill-name> - Activate a skill for current project - list - List active skills for current project - deactivate <name> - Deactivate a skill - show <name> - Show skill details - auto - Auto-activate recommended skills for project type - available - List all available user-level skills

Options: - -f, --force - Force activation (override existing) - -h, --help - Show help message

Examples: 

# Activate R package development skill
skill-activate r-package-development

# Auto-activate recommended skills
skill-activate auto

# List active skills
skill-activate list

# Show available skills
skill-activate available

# Show skill details
skill-activate show r-package-development

# Deactivate a skill
skill-activate deactivate simulation

How Skills Work: - Skills are stored in ~/.claude/skills/ (user-level) - Activated via symlinks to .claude/skills/ in project - Allows shared skills across all projects - Supports project-specific overrides - Easy activation/deactivation without copying files

Common Skills: - r-package-development - R package development best practices - statistical-simulation - Statistical simulation workflows - quarto-publishing - Quarto document publishing - manuscript-writing - Academic manuscript writing

docs.title: Branch Protection Setup
docs.text: This guide explains how to configure GitHub branch protection for the main branch to maintain stability.

docs.title: Why Branch Protection?
docs.text:
• main branch auto-deploys to GitHub Pages
  • Keep main always stable and deployable
  • Prevent accidental direct commits to main
  • Ensure all changes go through dev branch first

docs.title: For main Branch
docs.text:
Go to: Settings → Branches → Add branch protection rule

Branch name pattern: main

docs.title: Protection Rules
docs.text:
✅ Require a pull request before merging - Required approvals: 1 (or 0 for solo maintainer) - Dismiss stale pull request approvals when new commits are pushed - ❌ Do NOT require review from Code Owners (optional)

✅ Require status checks to pass before merging - ❌ Require branches to be up to date before merging (optional) - Status checks: Add if you have CI/CD workflows

✅ Require conversation resolution before merging

✅ Include administrators - Even admins must follow the rules

❌ Do not allow bypassing the above settings

docs.title: Additional Settings
docs.text:
✅ Require linear history - Keeps git history clean

✅ Allow force pushes → Specify who can force push - Add yourself only if needed for emergency fixes

✅ Allow deletions → ❌ (keep unchecked) - Prevents accidental branch deletion

docs.title: For dev Branch (Optional)
docs.text:
Branch name pattern: dev

Lighter protection: - ❌ No PR required (you can commit directly) - ✅ Require status checks if you have CI/CD - ❌ No approval required

docs.title: Context Management
docs.text: Learn how zsh-claude-workflow gathers and manages context for Claude Code integration.

docs.title: What is Context?
docs.text:
Context includes all information Claude Code needs to understand your project:

  • CLAUDE.md files - Project-specific instructions
  • Project structure - Directory organization
  • Git information - Branch, status, recent commits
  • Type-specific data - R package stats, Quarto config, etc.
  • Storage information - Location and tier

docs.title: CLAUDE.md
docs.text:
Primary instruction file for Claude Code:

Location Priority: 1. ./CLAUDE.md (project root) 2. ./.claude/CLAUDE.md (hidden directory) 3. ../CLAUDE.md (parent directory)

Multiple Files: - System finds all CLAUDE.md files in hierarchy - All files are presented to Claude Code - More specific files take precedence

docs.title: Claude Settings
docs.text:
Claude Code configuration files:

Files: - ./.claude/settings.json - Project settings - ./.claude/settings.local.json - Local overrides

docs.title: Automatic Context
docs.text:
The claude-ctx command automatically gathers:

claude-ctx

Output: - List of all CLAUDE.md files found - Content of primary CLAUDE.md - Claude settings files - Project metadata

docs.title: Context Summary
docs.text:
The proj-info command provides full context:

proj-info

Includes: - Project type and name - Storage location and tier - Git status and branch - CLAUDE.md files - Type-specific information - Project structure

docs.title: R Package Context
docs.text:
Additional Information: - Package name and version - R/ directory file count - tests/ directory status - Dependencies from DESCRIPTION - NAMESPACE exports

Example: 

cd ~/R-packages/active/rmediation
proj-info

docs.title: Quarto Project Context
docs.text: Additional Information: - Project title and type - Number of .qmd files - _quarto.yml configuration - Output formats

docs.title: Research Project Context
docs.text: Additional Information: - LaTeX files count - Bibliography files - Literature directory status

docs.title: Creating CLAUDE.md
docs.text:
Use claude-init to create from template:

cd ~/R-packages/active/newpkg
claude-init

This creates a project-specific CLAUDE.md based on detected project type.

docs.title: Viewing Context
docs.text:
Use claude-show to display CLAUDE.md:

claude-show

Uses bat for syntax highlighting if available, otherwise uses cat.

docs.title: Editing CLAUDE.md
docs.text:
Edit directly:

vim CLAUDE.md
# or
code CLAUDE.md

docs.title: Multiple CLAUDE.md Files
docs.text:
When multiple files exist:

~/R-packages/active/rmediation/
├── CLAUDE.md              # Project-specific (highest priority)
└── .claude/
    └── CLAUDE.md          # Alternative location

The system shows all files and their locations.

docs.title: Global vs Project Context
docs.text:
Global Context: - ~/.claude/CLAUDE.md - User-wide preferences - Applied to all Claude Code sessions

Project Context: - ./CLAUDE.md - Project-specific instructions - Overrides or extends global context

docs.title: Git Context
docs.text:
Automatically included context:

  • Current branch
  • Uncommitted changes
  • Recent commits (last 5)
  • Remote repository URL

Access:

docs.title: Storage Context
docs.text:
Location and tier information:

Helps Claude understand: - Project stability (active vs archive) - Collaboration needs (local vs cloud) - Backup status

docs.title: Project Structure
docs.text:
Automatically generated file tree:

proj-info  # Includes structure

Limited to relevant directories and files for Claude.

docs.title: What to Include in CLAUDE.md
docs.text: ✅ Project-specific conventions - Naming patterns unique to your project ✅ Common tasks - Frequent operations Claude should know ✅ Architecture decisions - Important design choices ✅ Dependencies - Key libraries and their purposes ✅ Testing approach - How tests are organized and run

docs.title: What to Avoid
docs.text: ❌ Generic programming advice - Claude knows general patterns ❌ Obvious information - Directory structure Claude can see ❌ Outdated instructions - Keep it current or remove it ❌ Too much detail - Focus on what's non-obvious

docs.text:
The proj-claude command:

  1. Gathers all context
  2. Displays context summary
  3. Launches Claude Code
  4. Claude Code reads CLAUDE.md automatically

Usage: 

cd ~/R-packages/active/rmediation

docs.text: This guide covers setting up a professional ZDOTDIR configuration with antidote + Oh My Zsh optimization, following 2025 best practices.

docs.title: What is ZDOTDIR?
docs.text: ZDOTDIR is an environment variable that tells Zsh where to find its configuration files. Instead of cluttering your home directory with 13+ zsh dotfiles, ZDOTDIR lets you organize everything in one clean location.

docs.title: Benefits
docs.text:
• ✅ Clean home directory - Only 1 file (~/.zshenv) instead of 13+
  • ✅ Better organization - All zsh configs in one place
  • ✅ XDG-compliant - Follows modern configuration standards
  • ✅ Easier backups - Just backup ~/.config/zsh/
  • ✅ Easier management - Everything grouped logically

docs.title: Architecture Overview
docs.text:
~/
├── .zshenv                   # ONLY file in home (sets ZDOTDIR)
│
└── .config/zsh/              # ALL zsh configuration (ZDOTDIR)
    ├── .zshrc               # Main configuration
    ├── .zsh_plugins.txt     # Antidote plugin list
    ├── .p10k.zsh           # Powerlevel10k theme
    ├── conf.d/             # Modular configs (optional)
    ├── functions/          # Lazy-loaded functions (optional)
    └── completions/        # Custom completions (optional)

docs.title: Step 1: Create ZDOTDIR Structure
docs.text:
# Create directory structure
mkdir -p ~/.config/zsh/{conf.d,functions,completions}

docs.title: Step 2: Create ~/.zshenv
docs.text:
Create ~/.zshenv in your home directory (this is the ONLY file that stays in home):

# ~/.zshenv
# ============================================
# ZDOTDIR CONFIGURATION
# ============================================

export ZDOTDIR="$HOME/.config/zsh"

# ============================================
# HOMEBREW INITIALIZATION
# ============================================
# Initialize Homebrew before .zshrc runs

if [[ -f /opt/homebrew/bin/brew ]]; then
  # Apple Silicon
  eval "$(/opt/homebrew/bin/brew shellenv)"
elif [[ -f /usr/local/bin/brew ]]; then
  # Intel Mac
  eval "$(/usr/local/bin/brew shellenv)"
fi

docs.title: Step 3: Move Existing Configs
docs.text:
# Backup first!
cp ~/.zshrc ~/.zshrc.backup
cp ~/.zsh_plugins.txt ~/.zsh_plugins.txt.backup

# Move to ZDOTDIR
mv ~/.zshrc ~/.config/zsh/.zshrc
mv ~/.zsh_plugins.txt ~/.config/zsh/.zsh_plugins.txt
mv ~/.p10k.zsh ~/.config/zsh/.p10k.zsh  # if using Powerlevel10k

docs.title: Step 4: Update Paths in .zshrc
docs.text:

# OLD
[[ ! -f ~/.p10k.zsh ]] || source ~/.p10k.zsh
antidote load ~/.zsh_plugins.txt

# NEW
[[ ! -f $ZDOTDIR/.p10k.zsh ]] || source $ZDOTDIR/.p10k.zsh
antidote load $ZDOTDIR/.zsh_plugins.txt
